image.altText: People stand at the water's edge to watch fireworks.

props.synopsis: It happens just once a year, for five loud, chaotic hours — and only in one rebellious corner of the country. See how the Northern Territory celebrated Cracker Night in pictures.

title.children: 'The Wild West': The Northern Territory's Cracker Night in pictures

image.altText: A bearded man in a red shirt standing in a doorway

props.synopsis: Northern Territory retailers are warning of business closures and job losses amid a delayed crackdown on a controversial Centrelink payment system that advocates say exploits remote Aboriginal customers.

title.children: Remote retailers facing 'collapse' amid Centrepay crackdown

image.altText: A man in a lab coat holds up a pair of sample jars containing soil.

props.synopsis: The soil-borne disease continues to pose a threat in Queensland's north following extremely wet conditions this year.

title.children: Another melioidosis case recorded in northern Australia as two more deaths confirmed

image.altText: A waterfall on a rocky landscape, with green trees growing on all sides of the water.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's popular Litchfield National Park is set to expand by 20 per cent, giving Territorians and visitors more places to camp, four-wheel drive, swim and hunt.

title.children: Popular waterfalls to join Litchfield National Park in 30,000ha expansion

image.altText: Three poker machines in a club with brightly coloured screens showing different gambling games, with three empty stools in front

props.synopsis: Not-for-profit pokies clubs in the Northern Territory are supposed to contribute part of their profits for the benefit of the wider community, but data shows some are effectively opting out of the voluntary scheme.

title.children: Clubs accused of 'whitewashing' pokies revenue through benefit scheme

image.altText: A silhouette of a woman's head and shoulders.

props.synopsis: Parents of potential victims of alleged child sex offender Joshua Dale Brown speak of their horror at finding out their children could have been abused or contracted STIs.

title.children: 'Seemed quite friendly': Parents of potential victims of alleged childcare abuser speak

image.altText: A large dam in a regional area with water spilling over a reservoir on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: Severe weather warnings have been downgraded but emergency services warn damaging winds will linger around the NSW coast today.

title.children: Warnings remain for NSW coast, Warragamba Dam spills

image.altText: The top of UTS Tower visible over red corrugated rooves of a warehouse.

props.synopsis: The University of Technology Sydney is being investigated by SafeWork over "psychological hazards" arising from a restructure with other universities also wielding the axe.

title.children: UTS staff member risks sack to speak out against 'devastating' plan for mass redundancies

image.altText: Close up of man wearing glasses

props.synopsis: Joshua Maxwell was told his open-heart surgery had to be done within 90 days. He thought he was going to die as the wait extended beyond 200 days.

title.children: Joshua waited over 200 days for life-saving surgery at troubled hospital

image.altText: A photo of Patricia McGarry outside her home

props.synopsis: After falling behind on mortgage repayments, this home owner says she often forgoes meals to feed her cats. Recent data shows she's not alone.

title.children: Patricia finally bought her own home at age 60. Now she faces losing it all

image.altText: People recline on marble steps outside the US Captiol. The building's domed roof can be seen in the bakground

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump is getting closer to seeing his One Big Beautiful Bill Act passed after it narrowly passed a Senate vote. Here's why the bill isn't enjoying full Republican support.

title.children: Why Republicans are voting against Trump's Big Beautiful Bill

image.altText: President Donald Trump speaks to the media, Friday, June 27, 2025, in the briefing room of the White House in Washington.

props.synopsis: Media group Paramount will pay Donald Trump more than $24 million to settle a lawsuit filed over an interview with former US presidential rival Kamala Harris.

title.children: Paramount to pay Trump $24m over Harris interview lawsuit

image.altText: A man in a green hoodie sits on a brick wall holding a sign.

props.synopsis: The banking sector is rolling out a new system intended to combat scam losses by telling customers when a payment recipient's name does not match other account details.

title.children: Scam victim loses home deposit to a security flaw that banks are now targeting

image.altText: Man with rainbow hair wearing rainbow clothes steps into a rainbow party bus.

props.synopsis: There have been 23 courtroom places for the public in the Erin Patterson triple-murder trial. Competition for those seats starts early each morning.

title.children: People turning down work shifts to spend months at the mushroom trial

image.altText: Iranian president stands at a podium in front of an Iranian flag. He has short white hair.

props.synopsis: Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian has ordered the country to suspend its cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency after US and Israeli air strikes hit its key nuclear facilities.

title.children: Iran suspends cooperation with UN nuclear watchdog

image.altText: Tiered brick pyramid in sandy desert with line of people walking up to it.

props.synopsis: Researchers have sequenced the genome of an ancient Egyptian who was buried in a pot nearly 5,000 years ago, about the time some of the oldest, and most famous, pyramids were built.

title.children: DNA from skeleton in a pot reveals ancient Egyptian's ancestry

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The tech giant is cutting 4 per cent of its global workforce, including in Australia. Meanwhile, the fall-out from the Qantas cyber attack continues. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Microsoft axing jobs in Australia, while Wall Street rises on Trump-Vietnam trade deal

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Qantas starts telling customers their data was taken
Microsoft to lay off about 4pc of workforce
Reports of a tariff deal between US and Vietnam

image.altText: man with shaves head, orange and red robes sits on chat with woman with red and white hat waving arms.

props.synopsis: The Dalai Lama confirms his centuries-old tradition will continue, with his charitable foundation the only authority to recognise his future reincarnation.

title.children: Dalai Lama affirms succession plan for after his death, heartening supporters

image.altText: heatwave france july 2

props.synopsis: Four people have died in Spain, two in France and two in Italy as an early summer heatwave continues to grip much of Europe.

title.children: At least eight dead as heatwave in Europe closes nuclear reactor and fans fires

image.altText: Elliot Daly of the Lions is seen being treated for an injury by two medics, holding his left forearm

props.synopsis: The British and Irish Lions have continued their roaring start to the Australian tour, defeating the Queensland Reds 52-12.

title.children: Lions win soured as versatile fullback suffers suspected fractured arm

image.altText: Jordan Thompson preparing to hit a backhand shot on a grass tennis court

props.synopsis: Australian Jordan Thompson comes from behind to win a gruelling five-set match for the second time at Wimbledon this week.

title.children: Thompson wins another thriller, Aussie comedian shares crowd altercation

image.altText: GettyImages-2223282749

props.synopsis: Carlos Alcaraz, Emma Raducanu, Aryna Sabalenka and the end of London's tropical heatwave see a sense of normality return to the lawns of Wimbledon on day three.

title.children: Normality returns to Wimbledon as heavyweights win on day three

image.altText: A blonde teenager looks seriously at the camera with trees behind her

props.synopsis: More young Victorians are needing acute mental health support, but the number of beds to accommodate them is failing to keep up.

title.children: Young Victorians left waiting for acute mental health beds

image.altText: Curling players in action on the ice

props.synopsis: Four Brisbane dads discuss the need to find a new hobby over lunch and some red wine. Just over a year later, they have come so far that an Olympic bid is very much within the realms of possibility.

title.children: How 'unusual bunch' of Brisbane dads turned new hobby into an Olympic dream

image.altText: Bec Nolan with her husband and her three kids on the beach

props.synopsis: The mental load of juggling three young kids, while running a household with a husband who works long hours, and now caring for her mum with dementia, is "relentless", says Bec Nolan.

title.children: Bec is part of the 'sandwich generation'. She says it's relentless

image.altText: A large sign reading Greenough Regional Prison stands near a road in front of trees.

props.synopsis: Western Australia's Department of Justice relocates nine prisoners who allegedly plot to riot and take hostages at an "understaffed" prison, according to the prison officer's union.

title.children: Guards uncover inmate riot and hostage plot at 'overcrowded' prison

image.altText: India's Shubman Gill celebrates after reaching his century against England, roaring with delight

props.synopsis: India's Shubman Gill played a masterful captain's knock for his second century of the series against England at Edgbaston.

title.children: India on top after day one following surprise decision to rest Bumrah

image.altText: Ye wears a black tee and jeans, Censori wears a black fur coat

props.synopsis: The musician had a valid visa cancelled by officials in Tony Burke's department after he released a song titled Heil Hitler.

title.children: Minister reveals Kanye West was denied entry to Australia

image.altText: A photo of the painting The Birth of Venus being taken on a smartphone.

props.synopsis: Smart devices are becoming more sophisticated and we're increasingly using them to document our lives in minute detail. But research suggests this is changing the way we think — and remember.

title.children: Storing your life on your phone changes the way you think

image.altText: Researcher in scuba diving suit underwater conducting sampling on the reef

props.synopsis: A University of Queensland study has found the further coral disperses, the better chance reefs have at bouncing back from disaster.

title.children: Research shows coral larvae could be 'key' to restoring damaged reefs

image.altText: A woman smiling and holding a walking aid by being assisted by her physio

props.synopsis: Susan Blackborough was just 12 when she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis and was told she would lose her ability to walk.

title.children: MS took Susan's ability to walk, but she's determined to get it back

image.altText: A man standing in front of a blue painting smiles gently

props.synopsis: After controversially and suddenly withdrawing Khaled Sabsabi and Michael Dagostino from the 2026 Venice Biennale, Creative Australia has announced it has reversed its decision.

title.children: Khaled Sabsabi reinstated as Australia's representative at 2026 Venice Biennale

image.altText: Woman with blonde hair and floral dress sits in chair with slightly smiling expression.

props.synopsis: Torrey Peters' books have made history and created space for other trans authors to have a voice. And while there's plenty to battle against right now, she says trans people have more of a voice today than ever.

title.children: Torrey Peters' first book made trans history. Her second features lumberjacks

image.altText: A traditional-looking housewife smiles at the camera as she holds a pie standing in a pink-coloured pantry

props.synopsis: What is it about the tradwife movement and its strict traditional gender roles that has struck a chord with modern day mothers?

title.children: These modern stay-at-home mums are redefining what it means to be a tradwife
